The report is not correct. The alleged out‑of‑bounds read via strncpy/memchr is prevented by the preceding validation and initialization logic in this code path:

- phys_path is validated by OS_CHECK_STRING(phys_path, sizeof(filesys->system_mountpt), ...), which (via LENGTHCHECK) ensures that phys_path contains a terminating NUL within the checked bound. virt_path is similarly validated by OS_CHECK_PATHNAME. Thus any pointer derived from phys_path (dev_name = strrchr(...)) or the virt_path pointer has a NUL terminator within its accessible region as established by those checks.

- For the device-name case the code additionally calls memchr(dev_name, 0, sizeof(filesys->volume_name)) and returns an error if no NUL is found within that range. That ensures memchr will not read past the end of the phys_path string in the successful path and that the source contains a NUL within the searched range.

- The destination buffers are zeroed by OS_OBJECT_INIT (it calls memset(ref, 0, sizeof(*ref))) before the subsequent strncpy calls, so even when strncpy is invoked with sizeof(...)-1 (which will not append a NUL when truncation occurs), the destination remains NUL-terminated.

Given these checks and the prior zero-initialization, the use of memchr/strncpy does not cause accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters and therefore does not violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 in this implementation.
